text:
Is defining aliases for macros not supported on purpose? I mean the following:
```julia> function f() 1 end
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> macro m() 1 end
@m (macro with 1 method)

# aliasing function to another name works:
julia> ff = f
f (generic function with 1 method)

# doing the same with macros in not supported:
julia> @mm = @m
ERROR: syntax: unexpected "="
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ none:1```

text:
A macro expands into the syntax — if you write `const x = @m` , the macro expands on the RHS… you would have to use:
```const x = var"@m"```

text:
It allows turning things into variables that would otherwise be impossible to write. E.g.
```julia> var"#hi" = 1
1

julia> #hi

julia> var"#hi"
1```

text:
The variable generated by gensym is another example:
```julia> @gensym a

julia> a
Symbol("##a#246")

julia> :($a = 5)
:(var"##a#246" = 5)```
Used for macro sanitisation so that generated variables don't clash with written variables.
